page.title: 06SADDLEWORTH CHURCH
page.content: This was built about 1200AD, when such villages as Diggle did not exist. The sparse population was concentrated in small hillside hamlets such as Holly Grove & Pobgreen. By the end of the Middle Ages, the church had become a typical north-country perpendicular parish church. Due to the increasing population in the 18th century, inside galleries were built, & in 1746 a tower & clock were added. Its state deteriorated, & in 1830 the church was repaired & enlarged into today's form. Its rugged simplicity suits its bleak moorland setting. There is an adjacent graveyard, in which is Bill o'Jacks grave, & also one over the main road. It is the centre for old traditions such as the rushcart festival, where a service is held each year after the procession through the local villages. There are Church Walks on Whit Friday.
